sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using Cramer's rule
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations using Cramer's rule:

2x + 3y - z = 5
x - 2y + 4z = -7
3x + y - 2z = 6

Find the values of x, y, and z.
message_2:
To solve the given system of linear equations using Cramer's rule, we first need to find the determinant of the coefficient matrix (D), and then the determinants of the matrices obtained by replacing the columns with the constants (Dx, Dy, Dz).

The coefficient matrix is:
| 2  3 -1 |
| 1 -2  4 |
| 3  1 -2 |

To find the determinant D, we use the rule of Sarrus:
D = 2((-2)(-2) - 4(1)) - 3(1(-2) - 4(3)) - 1(1(1) - 3(-2))
D = 2(4 - 4) - 3(-2 - 12) - 1(1 + 6)
D = 2(0) + 3(14) + 1(7)
D = 0 + 42 + 7
D = 49

Now, we will find Dx, Dy, and Dz by replacing the respective columns with the constants.

For Dx, replace the first column with the constants (5, -7, 6):
| 5  3 -1 |
| -7 -2  4 |
| 6  1 -2 |

Dx = 5((-2)(-2) - 4(1)) - 3(-7(-2) - 4(6)) - 1(-7(1) - 6(-2))
Dx = 5(4 - 4) - 3(14 - 24) + 1(7 + 12)
Dx = 5(0) + 3(-10) + 1(19)
Dx = 0 - 30 + 19
Dx = -11

For Dy, replace the second column with the constants (5, -7, 6):
| 2  5 -1 |
| 1 -7  4 |
| 3  6 -2 |

Dy = 2((-7)(-2) - 4(6)) - 5(1(-2) - 4(3)) - 1(1(6) - 3(-7))
Dy = 2(14 - 24) - 5(-2 - 12) - 1(6 + 21)
Dy = 2(-10) + 5(14) - 1(27)
Dy = -20 + 70 - 27
Dy = 23

For Dz, replace the third column with the constants (5, -7, 6):
| 2  3  5 |
| 1 -2 -7 |
| 3  1  6 |

Dz = 2((-2)(6) - (-7)(1)) - 3(1(6) - (-7)(3)) - 5(1(1) - 3(-2))
Dz = 2(-12 + 7) - 3(6 + 21) - 5(1 + 6)
Dz = 2(-5) - 3(27) - 5(7)
Dz = -10 - 81 - 35
Dz = -126

Now, we can find the values of x, y, and z using the determinants:

x = Dx / D = -11 / 49
y = Dy / D = 23 / 49
z = Dz / D = -126 / 49

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is:

x = -11/49
y = 23/49
z = -126/49
